children.subject: from the classes in semesters, i would recommend doing 61c over the summer if you're only choosing one. 61c is much more time-consuming and is a prereq for some upper divs like 164 and 161 (not sure if that is strictly the case, but it would help you a lot in those).

history.content:
a lot of cs upperdivs assume some knowledge of 61C and in general 61C is really useful in helping you get a better understanding of fundamental ideas that can really change how you think about computers and memory.

if 61C is the only class you're focusing on in the summer it shouldn't be too terrible. It's a project a week. I took it over last summer and it was alright.

Parts of the class were very tedious but imo it was all really interesting (at least on a high-level). The nitty-gritty wasn't hard but it could be really annoying.

I can't say that I really enjoyed myself while taking the class but of the 61 series it is the one I think back to the most. There are a lot of powerful ideas it introduces you to so maybe you'll find it interesting :^)

and I haven't taken 160 so I can't offer much advice on that

Parts of the class were very tedious but imo it was all really interesting (at least on a high-level). The nitty-gritty wasn't hard but usually it was annoying at times.

I can't say that I really enjoyed myself while taking the class but of the 61 series it is the one I think back to the most. There are a lot of powerful ideas it introduces you to so maybe you'll find it interesting :^)

I'm thinking of taking either CS61C or CS160 over the summer to get a head start on next year, and I'm trying to figure out which one I should take. I want to take 61C just to get it out of the way, but I've been hearing that it's really hard and really fast paced, hence why I am debating it vs. 160. Does anyone have any experience with taking 61C over the summer, or 160? Or just experience with the class in general. Any help or advice would be really appreciated, thank you.
history.subject: 61C vs 160 over summer sessions
